    "body": "Aside from database configuration and some other basic configurations, all of COmanage's configuration is stored in the database, and is expected to be administered through the web interface. For local development and testing, should we:\n\n1. Create a very basic configuration for local development, put an SQL file with that basic configuration under source control, and add to that configuration only when necessary to replicate and address bugs found in production?\n\n2. Replicate the production configuration as closely as possible, only leaving out sensitive data such as user accounts and API credentials?\n\nFollowing on these, should non-sensitive configuration be put under version control--ie. if we adopt choice (2), should local configuration changes be sync'd to production?\n\n## Survey of COmanage configuration\n\nThis is a survey of the COmanage configuration for Knowledge Commons, based on the production instance Configuration page. Sections with no configuration settings are skipped.\n\n| Section                         | Description                         | Sensitive Data? |\n|---------------------------------|-------------------------------------|-----------------|\n| CO Settings                     | General settings                    | No              |\n| API Users                       | Access to REST API                  | Yes             |\n| COUs                            | Organizations                       | No              |\n| Core APIs                       | R/W Person & Org                    | No              |\n| Dashboards                      | User dashboards                     | No              |\n| Enrollment Flows                | Enrollment flows                    | Yes - Wedges    |\n| Expiration Policies             | Org-level membership expiration     | No              |\n| Extended Types                  | Allows extending attribute options  | No              |\n| Identifier Assignments          | Extend types of identifiers         | No              |\n| Identifier Validators           | Allow validation of identifiers     | No              |\n| Localizations                   | Override default text in UI         | No              |\n| Organizational Identity Sources | Connect to external APIs            | Yes             |\n| Pipelines                       | Add users to orgs based on criteria | No              |\n| Provisioning Targets            | Provision from COmanage to LDAP, etc| Yes - LDAP creds|\n| Services                        | ? Not sure this is used             | No              |   \n| Terms and Conditions            | Text or URL of T&C                  | No              |\n| Themes                          | Org-level UI customization          | No              |\n\nBased on this survey, (2) would be feasible.\n\nOne further question is whether it would make sense to put a .sql file into version control, or whether we should instead have something like a custom YAML file that is used to generate an SQL file. That would take additional development but would be easier to maintain, especially if we are planning to have a mechanism for syncing configuration updates to production.     \n\n",

See descriptions below from ACRL reporting requirements.\n\n#50 - Digital items held in the intuitional repository(ies)\n \nReport the total number of items held in the library's hosted or administered institutional repositories.  Include all items whether created by library staff, faculty, students, college staff, or other guests.\n \n \n#51 - Digital item usage from the institutional repository\n \nReport the number of downloads from the institutional repository(ies) during the reported fiscal year.  If available, download counts are preferred.  However, if downloads are not available, usage statistics may include page views, visits or other data related to the access of the items in the institutional repository; please indicate which type of count you are providing.\n",

    "body": "Create a mechanism for specifying themes and plugins to be activated on base & user sites in code.\r\n\r\n## Motivation\r\n\r\nCurrently plugin and theme activations are controlled solely through the WP Admin interface. Combined with the large number of plugins and themes running on the Commons network, this causes many unintended differences in activations between sites. By specifying this in code, we can have a more reliable and maintainable way of managing themes and plugins across the network. This will also make launching new networks significantly easier, as currently there is significant effort require to configure new networks.\r\n\r\n## Implementation\r\n\r\nCreate a YAML file following the following pattern:\r\n\r\n```yaml\r\ndefault:\r\n    base-site-plugins:\r\n       - hc-custom\r\n       - bbpress\r\n       - classic-widgets\r\n       - ...\r\n    network-plugins:\r\n       - humanities-commons\r\n       - buddypress\r\n       - ...\r\n    allowed-user-plugins:\r\n       - mathml-block\r\n       - zotpress\r\n       - ...\r\n    allowed-user-themes:\r\n       - blockbase\r\n       - twentytwentythree\r\n    base-theme: boss-child\r\n    user-theme: twentytwentythree\r\nmla.hcommons.org:\r\n    base-site-plugins:\r\n       - -classic-widgets\r\n       - hc-auth\r\n    ...\r\nup.hcommons.org:\r\n    ...\r\ncommons.msu.edu:\r\n    ...\r\n```\r\n\r\nThis file first specifies a default configuration with the following properties:\r\n\r\n- `base-site-plugins` : Plugins activated on the base site of a network (hcommons.org, mla.hcommons.org, etc)\r\n- `network-plugins` : Plugins network-activated\r\n- `allowed-user-plugins` : Plugins that users are permitted to activate on their sites\r\n- `allowed-user-themes` : Themes that users are permitted to activate on their sites\r\n- `base-theme` : The theme active on the base site.\r\n- `user-theme` : The theme active by default on new user sites.\r\n\r\nNetworks may override the default settings for each of these. Plugins / themes specified in the list for a property are *added* to the default list, while those prefixed with a `-` are subtracted from the default list.\r\n\r\nThe constraints specified by the configuration file are enforced when:\r\n\r\n- The site is (re)launched\r\n- A new network is created\r\n- A user manages themes or plugins on their site\r\n\r\nAlready-active plugins & themes on user sites are not affected, so there will be no immediate impact on existing user sites.\r\n\r\n",

    "body": "**Describe the bug**\nWhen using admin edit to approve a CORE pending deposits, receive a \"Error - uploadMODS\" error. \n\n**To Reproduce**\nSteps to reproduce the behavior:\n1. Go to the pending CORE deposit (deposit notifications come from [this group](https://hcommons.org/groups/provisional-deposit-review/))\n2. Click on \"admin edit\"\n3. Change the status from \"pending review\" to \"draft\" using the edit button. \n4. Select \"OK\" and then \"Save Draft\"\n5. See error. If you hit the back button twice to go back to the deposit page, and then refresh, the status will change to \"provisional,\" which is what should happen.  \n\n**Expected behavior**\nA clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.\n\n**Context**\nDoes this bug on production, development, or both?\n- [ ] Tested on development instance\n- [ ] Occurs on development instance\n- [x] Tested on production\n- [x] Occurs on productions\n\n**Screenshots**\nIf applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.\n\n**Additional context**\nAdd any other context about the problem here.\n",

    "body": "The current IDMS stack exists over multiple long-running EC2 instances with services that have rarely been updated and are often not tracked in source control.\r\n\r\nThe primary aims of this project are:\r\n\r\n- Consolidate the IDMS stack in a single repository\r\n- Dockerize the IDMS stack for deployment on ECS or Kubernetes\r\n- Upgrade core services to current versions\r\n\r\nAdditionally, this project will include transitioning from PWM for password management to COmanage.\r\n\r\nOther than the transition from PWM, this project does not include any feature development. The aim is to rebuild the stack with feature parity to the current stack, which will facilitate feature development and maintenance in the future.\r\n\r\n## Overview of the current system\r\n\r\nSee also: [Humanities Commons Authentication and Identity Management Stack](https://github.com/MESH-Research/commons-docs/blob/main/documentation/developer/documentation/idms-stack.md)\r\n\r\n![KC IDMS Stack - IDMS Stack](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/859869b3-24d1-49cb-8811-4599924b53d2)\r\n[Miro](https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVPH6GGBA=/)\r\n\r\nThe Knowledge Commons IDMS stack provides identity information and authorizes users for two services: The [Knowledge Commons WordPress site](https://hcommons.org) and the [Knowledge Commons Works repository](https://works.hcommons.org). It consists of the following main services:\r\n\r\n- **SATOSA** (proxy.hcommons.org): Acts as a proxy between the KC applications and the KC identity providers. Also returns user information such as email address and organizational & group memberships to the applications upon successful authentication.\r\n- **COmanage Registry** (registry.hcommons.org): Manages a database that is the primary source of truth for user information. Handles user registration flows. Connects to external APIs to obtain organizational and group membership data. Provisions user data to LDAP.\r\n- **Registry LDAP** (registry.hcommons.org): Contains user and membership data. Provisioned to from COmanage. Queried by SATOSA.\r\n- **Shibboleth** (registry.hcommons.org): Duplicates Simplesamlphp functionality, specifically for logging in to COmanage. Probably redundant and unnecessary.\r\n- **Simplesamlphp** (hc-idp.hcommons.org): Does user authentication. For \"KC\" (username / password) login, checks credentials against PWM LDAP. For other login methods (Google, ORCID, MLA, etc), redirects to external IDP. When user successfully authenticates, redirect to SATOSA.\r\n- **PWM** (hc-idp.hcommons.org): Password manager. Provisions to PWM LDAP, which is queried by Simplesamlphp.\r\n- **PWM LDAP** (hc-idp.hcommons.org): Contains data *solely* for logging-in users with username and password.\r\n\r\n## User stories\r\n\r\n### User logs-in to Knowledge Commons using Google\r\n\r\n1. User clicks \"Login\" on Knowledge Commons (WordPress) site\r\n2. Proxy checks KC Wordpress entity id against metadata file, confirms KC WP is registered.\r\n3. User is redirected to SATOSA (proxy)\r\n4. User is redirected to discovery page (registry)\r\n5. User clicks \"Google\" login method\r\n6. User is redirected to Simplesamlphp Google gateway (google-gateway.hcommons.org)\r\n7. User authenticates with Google\r\n8. User is returned to Simplesamlphp (google-gateway.hcommons.org)\r\n9. User is redirected to SATOSA (proxy)\r\n10. SATOSA queries Registry LDAP for user data, matching against Google identifier\r\n11. SATOSA adds returned data to SAML assertion\r\n12. User is redirected to Knowledge Commons\r\n\r\n(Process is essentially the same for Works)\r\n\r\n### User logs-in to Knowledge Commons using \"KC\" (username / password) method\r\n\r\n1. User clicks \"Login\" on Knowledge Commons (WordPress) site\r\n2. Proxy checks KC Wordpress entity id against metadata file, confirms KC WP is registered.\r\n3. User is redirected to SATOSA (proxy)\r\n4. User is redirected to discovery page (registry)\r\n5. User clicks \"KC\" login method\r\n6. User is redirected to Simplesamlphp HC gateway (hc-idp.hcommons.org)\r\n7. User supplies username and password to Simplesaml PHP\r\n8. Simplesamlphp checks supplied credentials against those in PWM LDAP\r\n9. User is redirected to SATOSA (proxy)\r\n10. SATOSA queries Registry LDAP for user data, matching against hc-idp identifier\r\n11. SATOSA adds returned data to SAML assertion\r\n12. User is redirected to Knowledge Commons\r\n\r\n### User registers to Knowledge Commons\r\n\r\nSee also: [Enrollment Flows Flow (Miro)](https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVM3nULN4=/)\r\n\r\n1. User clicks \"Register\" on Knowledge Commons (WordPress) site\r\n2. User is shown some information about KC and registration\r\n3. User clicks \"Register now\"\r\n4. User is linked directly to an enrollment flow in COmanage (this is specific to each organization, so each \"Register now\" link on KC has to have a different URL.\r\n5. After successful enrollment (see \"Enrollment Flows Flow\" linked above), user is redirected to SATOSA\r\n6. SATOSA queries Registry LDAP for user data\r\n7. User is redirected back to Knowledge Commons\r\n8. WP recognizes that the user is authenticated but does not have an account. An account is created and the user is logged-in.\r\n\r\n## Redesigned IDMS stack\r\n\r\n![HC IDMS Stack - IDMS Redesign](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/73884159-2d18-47e0-8fe1-ad0f706f5ae9)\r\n[Miro](https://miro.com/app/board/uXjVPH6GGBA=/)\r\n\r\nReferencing the above diagram:\r\n\r\n- In contrast to the current stack, each service runs in its own container, rather than having services spread over multiple EC2 instances. This contrast is indicated by sharp-cornered rectangles in the diagram.\r\n- The most-common \"happy\" path for user login has arrows color-coded in red for the outward journey before successful authentication, and green for the return journey after.\r\n- As in the current system, MSU login does not go through Simplesamlphp but instead Okta communicates directly with SATOSA. This design decision might be revisited after the rebuild.\r\n- Application state exists in two locations: the database backing COmanage (\"RDS\") and the LDAP filesystem, which in production could be in EFS or EBS.\r\n- PWM has been removed, as discussed above. Password management is done by COmanage and provisioned to the LDAP along with other user data. The PWM Ldap has been removed.\r\n- Shibboleth has been removed, and COmanage is expected to use SATOSA / Simplesamlphp for login. This might need to be revisited if there is some unanticipated requirement of COmanage that can't be satisfied by Simplesamlphp.\r\n- An additional service, \"Discovery\" exists in the redesigned system. In the current system, the discovery page is served by the same Apache webserver that serves COmanage. In the redesign, discovery pages are served from a separate container, likely using Nginx.\r\n\r\n## Plan of Work\r\n\r\n- [x] Create IDMS stack repository\r\n- [ ] Copy configuration files and custom code to IDMS stack repository\r\n- [ ] Get services running in local dev containers\r\n    - [ ] SATOSA\r\n    - [ ] COmanage\r\n    - [ ] OpenLDAP\r\n    - [ ] Simplesamlphp\r\n    - [ ] Discovery\r\n- [ ] Create local SP stand-in for testing (takes the place of WP / Works when doing local dev)\r\n- [ ] Create local test configuration (COmanage DB)\r\n- [ ] Deploy dev stack to AWS for testing\r\n- [ ] Testing\r\n- [ ] Deploy to production \r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n",

    "body": "We should discuss current deposit takedown practices and options and the impacts. We should look at modifications to the process and future possible improvements. \"Soft removal\" in particuar, which is new, should be reviewed.\n\nCORE removal options\n\nEmbargo\n\nDownload becomes unavailable\nDOI remains public\nDOI metadata remains\nCORE landing page remains on site\nDeposited file remains in repo\nDeposit remains searchable\nAuthor profile entry remains\nAuthor ORCID entries remain\n\n\nSoft removal\n\nDOI made non-public\nBP activities removed ??\nSolr document removed ??\nHC URL redirected to /deposits/removed\nAuthor profile entries no longer available\nAuthor ORCID entries no longer resolve\n\nFull removal\n\nDOI made non-public\nDOI metadata removed\nBP activities removed\nSolr document removed\nFedora objects (2) removed\nUploaded file removed from HC directory\nHC URL redirected to /deposits/removed\nWP custom posts (2) removed\nAuthor profile entries no longer available\nAuthor ORCID entries no longer resolve\n\n\n",

    "body": "Create a workflow for adding a new theme to the Commons. Will exist as an issue template in admin-docs-support and as part of our developer documentation.\n\nFields for request:\n- Theme name\n- Link to theme page (eg. on wordpress.org)\n- Source of request (user request, internal request, etc)\n- Reason for request\n- Justification for adding according to below criteria:\n\n- Criteria for adding a theme to the Commons:\n    - The theme should be compatible with WordPress Full Site Editing\n    - The theme should be open source and freely available\n    - The theme should be distinct from existing themes on the Commons\n    - There should be evidence that the theme is actively maintained\n    - The theme should have a wide install base\n\nProcedure for approving\n\n- Determine that the theme sufficiently meets our criteria for inclusion\n- Create a testing procedure for the theme\n- Install and test the theme on staging server\n- Add user support documentation for theme\n- Add theme to theme inventory\n- Install theme on production\n\n",

    "body": "User Göktuğ Kayaalp - https://registry.hcommons.org/registry/co_people/canvas/70303 - has had issues with passwords for his HCID for about a month now. We finally got him in, but in working through it on his side he's found what may be a bug in the way we handle passwords. Can you check on this and fix it if it is the case? I don't know if this is a config issue or a code issue so I'm tagging both @mikethicke and @bboggmsu.\n\nThank you. I have tried again and I have both been able to change my\npassword and log in, and also I think that I’ve discovered what caused\nthe issue.\n\nI use a password manager app that auto-generates long random passwords\nfor me. These passwords include basic latin alphabet letters and\nnumbers, but also symbols such as &, \", etc., as well as “non-ascii”\ncharacters, such as latin letters with diacritics. When I generated such\na password with characters from all those categories, the password reset\nform accepted those (even displaying a green check mark ✔️), but when I\ntried to log in, it didn’t work, telling me my credentials were wrong\n(all this is with the HC login option).\n\nSuspecting, I tried generating a password with only non-diacritical\nlatin letters and numbers, and reset the password again. After that, I\nwas able to log in.\n\nSo the issue is with the password reset interface: it accepts passwords\nthat would not later be accepted at login. Knowing some programming, I\ncan imagine a couple scenarios why something like this might happen; it\nis a simple but frequent programming error.",

    "body": "- [ ] Add to an appropriate Epic\n\nDate first reported: N/A\nDate requested for completion: Originally October 2019\nSite: All\nArea (CORE, profiles, sites, groups, account ): Sites, Profiles\n\n**Description**\n\n- This WordPress plugin should be compatible with multi-network, multi-site and stand-alone WordPress installs and should not be enabled at the network level.\n- Use the WP Settings API to implement an admin configuration page to store user entered keys and system generated tokens. Restrict access to users with a role of author and above(see Settings API « WordPress Codex).\n- Retrieve the site user ORCID iD, store it in user meta and display it on the user profile.\n- The plugin should implement hooks necessary to be compliant with GDPR (see WP 4.9.6, Privacy, Hooks, and You).\n- Implement a short code that displays content retrieved from the /works API endpoint to allow non technical users to create custom pages (see API Tutorial: Read Data on a Record).\n- Implement caching of API requests using the WP cache API, provide a way for the site owner to refresh the cache.\n- (see MESH > Humanities Commons > ORCID Ingtegration > WP ORCID Integration for more info)\n\n**Steps to reproduce**\nN/A\n\n**Previous correspondence**\nRelated Trello card: https://trello.com/c/9S3JSq74/31-orcid-plugin-development-scope\n\n**Further details**\nAnything else we should know?\n\n**Trello link (if moved from Trello)**\nhttps://trello.com/c/srcRGmIc/36-wp-orcid-sync-plugin-phase-i",

    "body": "**Describe the bug**\nMultiple user sites and Commons network homepage are experiencing an issue where users receive an error message that reads, \"Error establishing a Redis connection\" \"To disable Redis, delete the object-cache.php file in the /wp-content/directory.\" This error is sporadic, in that it does not appear for all users and occurs across devices and browsers. For example, one user of HASTAC Commons has reported the issue on mobile in private browsing, while another reported it only in a non-private window.\n\nOne user reported they only receive the message when they type their site's URL into the browser. When they link to it from other sources it works. \n\nThe sites that this error has been reported are: \n[https://introdigitalstudies2024.commons.msu.edu](https://introdigitalstudies2024.commons.msu.edu)\n[https://aicommons.commons.msu.edu/](https://aicommons.commons.msu.edu/)\nMobile only: [hastac.hcommons.org](https://hastac.hcommons.org)\nMobile only: [up.hcommons.org](https://up.hcommons.org)",

    "body": "Multiple users have reported they are receiving repeated daily digest emails across various groups on the Commons. All of the users are reporting that they keep receiving the exact same email up to 8-10 times. I am still not totally clear on the timeframe the users are receiving them--in most cases, it sounds like the repeated emails are spread out over the course of a week, while another case sounded like the user received all of them in the span of a few hours. So far I've been contacted by three users, each for different groups--two are HCommons and one is MLA. These are the groups: [CLCS Medieval](https://mla.hcommons.org/groups/medieval/), [MSA Forum](https://hcommons.org/groups/msa-forum/), and [Literary Theory](https://hcommons.org/groups/literary-theory/).\n\n\n",

    "body": "AU Presses has noticed some changes in their groups since containerization. I'm copying and pasting their notes here. I have already answered the question about the site admin issue, and added the issue on post formatting to ISSUE LINK.\n\nFrom Kate: \nAs we've been using Groups since the refresh a couple of weeks ago, we've been experiencing some other issues of note. \n\n1. Events calendar: The option to submit a new event is unworkable at the moment. The calendar to select dates doesn’t pull up, there’s no option to select Groups, and there’s no submit button.\n2. Discussion tab: Now that it's called “Forum,” we can certainly change the language we use to talk to members about Groups. But we want to confirm that this change is intended and stable before we do so.\n3. Discussion topic posting: The authoring interface has changed a bit. The preview window is no longer available, and the published post will have tagging visible if it includes copy-pasted text—even if you don’t see the tags while you’re composing in the “Visual” setting.\n4. Accessibility: The new color scheme has made certain elements of Group functions visually inaccessible. The blue and green that now show up at the top of a discussion thread makes several key pieces of text unreadable. This is the case at a very specific time—just as soon as you’ve posted a discussion topic and it’s gone live. The background to the post title, “voices” and “replies” block, and the right sidebar are all a shade of blue that makes the text difficult to read. For example, the mint green is faint when used as text (as in “replies”) and dark grey text on top of the blue and mint green doesn’t offer a lot of contrast. I’ve attached a screenshot capturing this moment.\n5. Group site: Exploring the Board Group to identify other possible changes, Brenna clicked on “Site,” expecting to see that there wasn’t one. Instead, she got a warning that the site was only available to administrators of the site even though her account is an admin account and her role in the Group is as an administrator. (I can view the site.) In Group management, the “group blog” is turned on—even though we had not enabled it—with Group admin set as a default administrator of the related site. ",

    "body": "We are experiencing an ongoing issue with the AU Presses Board of Directors managed group. This started a few weeks ago when Kate first reported that a handful of users who were added to the group were continually booted, and users who should not have been in the group were still able to access it. I was able to identify that I could fix the issue by resyncing their org identity in CoManage, which seems like it temporarily fixes the issue. However, even after resyncing multiple times, there are still ongoing issues with this in the group. \n\nI'm thinking this is probably a syncing issue between Salesforce and CoManage. ",

    "body": "## Description ##\r\n\r\nRebuild a containerized version of the Knowledge Commons WordPress stack.\r\n\r\n## Background ##\r\n\r\nHumanities Commons currently runs on an EC2 instance. There are four repositories that contain code necessary for its core functionalities:\r\n\r\n- [commons](https://github.com/MESH-Research/commons): Scaffolding, based on [Bedrock](https://roots.io/bedrock/), and must-use plugins for the base site.\r\n- [humanities-commons](https://github.com/MESH-Research/humanities-commons): Network-activated plugin for multi-network Commons functionality.\r\n- [hc-custom](https://github.com/MESH-Research/hc-custom): Functionality specific to base / organizational Commons sites. Not network-activated.\r\n- [boss-child](https://github.com/MESH-Research/boss-child): Child theme of BuddyBoss active on base / organizational Commons sites.\r\n\r\nFunctionality from boss-child is being moved to hc-custom. The remaining three repositories should be merged into a single repository.\r\n\r\nThe original Humanities Commons stack used Ansible for managing configuration and deployment. PHP Composer was used for managing WordPress core, plugin, and theme updates. We have drifted away from these tools to direct plugin updates and scripts for syncing between production and development.\r\n\r\n## Deliverables ##\r\n\r\n- Single repository for core Knowledge Commons functionalities.\r\n- Repository should have directory structure corresponding to previous commons, humanities-commons, and hc-custom repositories.\r\n- Docker / Lando build process for local development.\r\n- Single Docker container that can be deployed to production.\r\n- Development / staging / production environment support.\r\n- PHP Composer used for WordPress core, plugin, and theme installation and updates.\r\n- Integrates with containerized IDMS stack.\r\n\r\n## Target Timeline ##\r\n\r\n- [ ] Production release: 06-30\r\n- [ ] Production-ready: 06-23\r\n- [ ] Testing complete: 06-01\r\n- [ ] Ready for testing: 05-15\r\n\r\n## Responsibilities ##\r\n\r\n**Development Lead**: Mike\r\n**Community Lead**: Bonnie\r\n\r\n",

    "body": "## Overview\n\nTo add a plugin to the Commons, we want to ensure that it fulfills a need for our users that cannot be addressed with our currently available plugins and themes, that it works with our configuration, and that we can adequately test it. Once a plugin is being used, it becomes very difficult to remove without causing problems, so we want to be very careful about adding plugins that will increase our support burden and might cause problems along the way.\n\n## Checklist\n\n- [x] Make plugin request (see below)\n- [ ] Initial evaluation (see below)\n- [ ] Install plugin on dev / staging for testing\n- [ ] Plugin works without issue?\n- [ ] Add plugin to plugin catalogue\n- [ ] Add necessary support documentation\n- [ ] Create test script for plugin and add to plugin catalogue\n- [ ] Install plugin on production\n- [ ] Notify users, possible blog post\n\n## Plugin Request Form\n\nPlugin Name: Translate Wordpress - Google Language Translator\nPlugin URL: [https://wordpress.org/plugins/google-language-translator/](https://wordpress.org/plugins/google-language-translator/)\nRequesting User: Meredith Hale (ARLIS/NA)\nRationale: See description below from Meredith about adding this plugin to ARLIS/NA sites:\n\nI've previously brought it to the attention of support staff that ARLIS/NA members would like to have a plugin for Wordpress sites to support translation. In particular, the Texas-Mexico Chapter and the MOQ (Montreal, Ottawa, Quebec) Chapter of ARLIS/NA would like their sites to be able to be translated to Spanish and French respectively. They previously had plugins on their old Wordpress sites prior to migration to the Commons and it is important to them to continue to make their sites accessible to all their members. Potentially the following plugin could meet those needs - [https://wordpress.org/plugins/google-language-translator/](https://wordpress.org/plugins/google-language-translator/)\n\n## Initial Evaluation\nCan the plugin's use case be (nearly) covered by existing functionality?\nIs the plugin free and open source?\nHigh active installations (wordpress.org)?\nIs 'WP Hive Insights' (wordpress.org) all green?\nIs plugin compatible with block editor?\nIs the plugin superior to similar alternatives?",
